Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Strongly Correlated Photons in Microwave Cavities and Coupled Cavity Arrays
Award.AbstractNarration:
*****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT*****
This Faculty Early Career Award supports a project aiming to understand the matter-like properties of light that emerge when photons begin to interact with one another. While scientists have developed a good understanding of the physics of individual particles, problems become vastly more complicated when these particles begin to interact. Particles of light, called photons, provide a unique tool for studying how the behavior of a system changes as interactions are turned on, as they do not naturally interact with one another. Through this award, systems that can have strong photon interactions will be constructed, and the novel behavior of these interacting photons will be measured. It is believed that, when interactions are turned on, photons will undergo phase transitions, acting more like matter than light. The primary goal of this award is to demonstrate this effect experimentally. This research program will be integrated into an educational program that aims to improve technical education at all levels: graduate, undergraduate, K-12, and general interest. Through graduate and undergraduate research opportunities, this award will create specific expertise in condensed matter physics and quantum optics, and train students in generally applicable technical skills, including nano- and microfabrication and high precision data acquisitions and analysis. K-12 education and general outreach will be incorporated through the platform of the Princeton Center for Complex Materials. This award receives support from the Divisions of Materials Research and Physics.

*****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT*****
This Faculty Early Career Award supports a project aiming to understand the effects of strong interactions between photons in arrays of superconducting microwave cavities. Strong correlations have remained at the forefront of condensed matter physics for some time, with many problems still proving difficult to solve theoretically. This project will provide experimental insight into the physics of correlated states of photons in coupled cavity arrays, a field that has a growing theoretical foundation but little experiment thus far. When photon-photon interactions are large, matter-like properties of light such as quantum phase transitions are expected to emerge. Although photons do not in general interact, effective photon interactions will be achieved by implementing a circuit quantum electrodynamics system, in which photons are strongly coupled to a superconducting qubit. The primary research goal is to experimentally probe these correlated photon effects. Specific research goals include (1) probing photon blockade due to strong off-resonant interactions in a single cavity and (2) demonstrating phase transitions of light in coupled cavity arrays. More broadly, these experiments will lay the groundwork for studies of the exotic correlated photon states that emerge from quantized photonic systems with strong interactions. These research results will be integrated into an educational program that aims to improve technical education at all levels: graduate, undergraduate, K-12, and general interest, including graduate and undergraduate research opportunities and outreach through the platform of the Princeton Center for Complex Materials. This award receives support from the Divisions of Materials Research and Physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this grant was to study the matter-like properties of light when interactions between photons become strong.  Specifically, we explored the emergence of complex phenomena from simple parts far out of equilibrium.  While this is primarily a problem of interest to physicists at the moment, understanding the emergence of non-equilibrium many-body effects is one of the Department of Energy’s grand challenges of basic energy science, and provides key insight into this important technological area in the future.  Our work uses arrays superconducting microwave cavities and artificial atoms to create the backbone for these emergent states of light.  In a small-scale system, we were able to observe a phase transition of light for the first time.

Light comprises one of the most fundamentally non-equilibrium systems, as particle number is not conserved and, without further excitation, eventually all light vanishes.  In typical situations, however, light is not a particularly interesting quantum system.  It behaves quite differently than matter because photons, unlike most particles, do not interact, and interactions give rise to the rich and complex physics of many-body systems.  Recently, however, physicists have begun to consider what would happen to light in systems where interactions were turned on, and have predicted that many new and exciting matter-like behaviors emerge for interacting photons in lattices of coupled cavities.  Just as optical lattices of cold atoms have provided a new toolbox for addressing condensed matter problems in equilibrium, so too will these coupled cavity experiments provide new insight into the physics of highly correlated systems out of equilibrium.

In our work, we observed for the first time a phase transition of light, where interactions between photons cause light to “freeze” in a pair of cavities.  We built a superconducting circuit that created artificial photon-photon interactions.  When these interactions were weak, photons were able to freely move between two cavities in the circuit; however, as interactions became stronger, the photons underwent a phase transition, locking in place in a single cavity.  This experiment is the first time that such matter-like properties of light have been observed, and has led to new insight into physics of non-equilibrium systems.  Even this simple experiment is at the limit of what is tractable to simulate on a classical computer, so we are indeed pushing beyond the computable limit.  And, this experiment is only the beginning.  Ongoing theoretical and experimental work in our lab seeks to extend this to large-scale systems and to create effective magnetic fields for photons, leading to the emergence of even more exotic states of light.

To better understand the complex phenomena in these arrays, a new scanned probe has been developed.  This new probe uses a moveable sapphire probe to locally shift a single cavity frequency by changing the effective dielectric constant.  This scanned defect alters the transmission properties of the lattice.  In particular, the transmission spectrum is affected in proportion to the weight of photon transport for a given frequency at a given lattice site, thus allowing a spatial map to be reconstructed for spectral information and probe position.  To implement this new approach, a cryogenic nanopositioning system was added to the base plate of a dilution refrigerator, allowing simultaneous measurement and positioning at ultra-low temperatures.  The tool was demonstrated to work using linear cavity lattices, and will be useful in the work of this proposal for imaging with single lattice site resolution in lattices with strong interactions.
